emails.subject: Wing test needed ASAP!
emails.body: Hey, Flairbus are on my back about their latest wing design. I need you to send over the first natural frequency by tomorrow. I'd recommend estimating frequency from the unforced time-domain response. Have a look in your toolkit and see what you can do.

results.name: First natural frequency
results.praise: Nice one! The client will be pleased with such a quick turnaround. You are able to estimate the first natural frequency from the unforced (or free) testing as the first mode usually dominated the response of free testing. Finding the higher modes is usually not possible using free testing

feedback.message: Hmm, your measured natural frequency is not quite right. Remember, frequency is 1/T, where T is the period of a single oscillation.
Try again, making sure to maximise your sampling frequency to get the highest possible measurement resolution.

Our in-house testing gives a first natural frequency of 100 Hz. Free testing is usually dominated by the first mode, which means the first natural frequency can be simply measured by calculating the inverse of a period of a single oscillation.

emails.subject: Modal test data needed
emails.body: I need a quick and rough estimate of the first three natural frequencies of the wing before my next stakeholder meeting. Please setup a test (NOTE: the wing is too stiff to execute free vibration testing in this case) and measure the second natural frequency. Time is of the essence!

results.name: Experimental setup
results.praise: Great! A hammer test provides a quick and simple test considering the constraints of the task. Hard tip also enabled excitation of the all required modes as its initial shape is already 'made up' of different higher modes.

feedback.message: One or more of the parameters in your test setup is incorrect. Focus on the excitation method.
Given that Hammer testing should be used, which tip hardness enables excitation of the greatest number of modes?

Hard tip hammer testing is ideal as it is quick to execute (does not require a shaker). Soft tip hammer testing usually does not excite higher modes as its initial shape is sufficiently made up of the first mode.

results.name: Second natural frequency
results.praise: Correct! You successfully setup an appropriate test and employed the discrete Fourier transform. The DFT is suffcient in identifying modal frequencies. However, in real world an FRF plot is used more commonly as it provides more information on the amplitude of the response and the structure behaviour in operation.

feedback.message: That doesn't seem to match our simulations. Make sure you are using Hammer testing. Make use of the DFT graph for easier identification of the the natural frequencies.
Not quite, read carefully off the DFT graph.
Our in-house testing gives a second natural frequency of 150 Hz. This is approximately the position of the second peak in the DFT.

emails.subject: Modelling vibration caused by engine
emails.body: In an aircraft wing, the engine (which vibrates a lot!) is usually located at the middle of the wing. We need you to conduct a modal test to simulate the dynamics.

results.name: Experimental setup
results.praise: Nice one! You have setup the test correctly.

feedback.message: Not quite, make sure you are exciting the structure from where the engine would be located.
The correct excitation location is at l/2.

results.name: What error is likely to occur when sampling at low frequency?
results.praise: Correct! Aliasing occurs when the signal contains frequency content at greater than half the sampling frequency (half the sampling frequency is called Nyquist frequency). This is why the response frequency is measured incorrectly.

feedback.message: Unfortunately that is not correct. This error is associated with the concept of 'Nyquist frequency'.
Unfortunately that is not correct.
Aliasing is the correct answer. Aliasing occurs when the signal contains frequency content at greater than half the sampling frequency.

emails.subject: We need modal damping ratios!
emails.body: Hello, I've heard big things about your modal testing expertise. Please can you produce a Nyquist plot and use it to estimate modal damping ratios?

results.name: Radius of the circle
results.praise: That is correct! Since the circle is centred on the real axis and starts from the origin, the radius is simply the x-value of the centre coordinate for mobility Nyquist. The radius provides information on the value of a/m of the structure, obtained from the equation of motion.

feedback.message: Not quite, try using Sine sweep with maximum sampling frequency for higher resolution.
Unfortunately that is not correct. Remember, the point where the Nyquist plot crosses the x-axis is approximately the diameter of the circle.
Our finite element simulations give a radius of 20. Since the circle is centred on the real axis and starts from the origin, the radius is simply the x-value of the centre coordinate.

results.name: Third natural frequency
results.praise: Well done! The natural frequency is where the mobility Nyquist plot crosses the real axis. This is also where the sweep rate is at its maximum. For flawed data, the natural frequencies sometimes are not located where the plot crosses the x-axis. The location of maximum sweep rate is a more reliable method of identifying natural frequencies.

feedback.message: Not quite, look for the frequency where the sweep rate is at its maximum.
Try reading off the frequency where the circle crosses the real axis.
The third natural frequency should be roughly 200 Hz. The natural frequency is where the mobility Nyquist plot crosses the real axis. This is also where the sweep rate is at its maximum.

results.name: Third modal damping ratio
results.praise: Spot on! This is the most accurate estimate of zeta from the plot. A simpler method of using the circle-fitting equation for damping is to take the points 90 degrees from the natural frequency point.

feedback.message: It might be easier to find the angle subtended from the origin to the point of interest and use angle identities.

The half-power method, which simplifies the damping ratio circle-fitting equation, can also be applied on Nyquist plot to find damping ratio. Use the frequency point at 90 degrees from the point corresponding to the natural frequency (maximum sweep rate).
The third modal damping ratio is expected to be around 20% using the half-power method.

emails.subject: Mode shapes on my desk by this afternoon
emails.body: Hello, we've just had some new clients adopt the Flairbus wing design and they're encountering issues with large wing tip deflections. Given that the engine is rotating at 9000 rpm, identify which mode this is likely to be exciting. Then we need an estimate for the mode shape of this mode ASAP. I'd recommend starting by producing an imaginary FRF plot. Mode shapes can be found by the ratios of the imaginary peaks at different measurement locations. Good luck, we're depending on you here!

results.name: Mode of vibration
results.praise: Perfect! The engine is rotating at 9000 rpm = 150 Hz which is approximately the second natural frequency. Note that it is entirely possible for the engine to excite multiple modes, but it is reasonable to guess that it is most likely to excite the second mode here.

feedback.message: Double check that you're converting your units of rotational speed to Hz correctly. Using the wrong unit can lead to misidentification of mode.
Try a different excitation method when estimating natural frequency.

results.name: Experimental setup
results.praise: Correct! You have setup the test correctly to measure accelerations in the second mode of vibration. It is possible to use other excitation methods, but sine sweep is suitable here as it is fast and can be set to include the expected operational frequencies.

feedback.message: Pick an excitation method which provides information over a range of frequencies, especially if we want to target the operational frequencies of the structure.
Double check the placement of your accelerometers. Mode shape is best estimated using accelerometers placed at equal distance from each other

results.name: Second mode shape
results.praise: Perfect! Our finite element models agree with this observation. There are many methods to estimate mode shapes, but the ratio of imaginary peaks is a good starting point for receptance FRF plots. For mobility, real peaks are commonly used while for inertance, imaginary peaks can be used provided that necessary scaling are done.

feedback.message: Make sure you are comparing ratio of imaginary peaks at different measurement locations at the same natural frequencies.
It is always a good idea to normalise the peaks so that the maximum peak will be 1, and other peaks are the ratio of that maximum peak.

results.name: Second modal damping ratio
results.praise: Perfect! Our finite element models agree with this observation. Remember there are two different methods to obtain modal damping ratios: half-power method on Bode plot and circle-fitting method on mobility Nyquist plot. Circle-fitting method is used more widely as effects of noises are compensated through fitting a circle through data points

feedback.message: Damping ratio for forced vibration can be measured using half-power method on Bode plot.
Remember there are two different methods to obtain modal damping ratios. If you are struggling with half power method on Bode plot, maybe try circle-fitting method on mobility Nyquist plot.

results.name: You may have noticed signifcant noise in the DFT. What might be causing this problem?
options: The recorded time-domain signals are not periodic over the DFT window.
The application of a digital filter has removed useful frequency components as well as noise.
results.answer: The recorded time-domain signals are not periodic over the DFT window.
results.praise: Correct! Leakage occurs when the time-domain signal is not periodic over the DFT window. This can result in the appearance of frequency peaks which, in reality, are not present in the measured time-domain signal.
